Columbia and Princeton are the only members of the Ivy League that have made 100 percent

of Native American remains available for return to Indigenous communities.

A majority of each of Harvard, Brown, Dartmouth, and Penn’s stolen remains are unavailable for return. As for other institutions in New York City, the

Brooklyn Children’s Museum and the Rome Historical Society have made 100 percent of remains available for return, while the Staten Island Institute

of Arts and Sciences has yet to make any of its stolen remains available for return.

Ivy League

Available for Return

Unavailable for Return

Columbia

100% (remains of at least 14 individuals)

Princeton

100% (19)

Cornell

25% (1)

75% (3)

Yale

53% (406)

47% (366)

Dartmouth

40% (10)

60% (15)

Harvard

39% (3,861)

61% (6,165)

Penn

36% (228)

64% (404)

Brown

11% (12)

89% (99)

Other Institutions in New York City

Available for Return

Unavailable for Return

Brooklyn Children’s Museum

100% (remains of at least 3 individuals)

Rome Historical Society

100% (87)

NYU College of

Dentistry

57% (151)

43% (113)

American Museum of

Natural History

46% (1,628)

54% (1,938)

Brooklyn Museum

20% (1)

80% (4)

Staten Island Institute of

Arts and Sciences

100% (4)

Note: Number of remains are self-reported by institutions to the federal government through the Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act.

Source: ProPublica, The Repatriation Project

Graphic by Laya Gollamudi

Columbia and Princeton are the only members of the Ivy League

that have made 100 percent of Native American remains

available for return to Indigenous communities.

A majority of each of Harvard, Brown, Dartmouth, and Penn’s stolen remains are unavailable for

return. As for other institutions in New York City, the Brooklyn Children’s Museum and the Rome

Historical Society have made 100 percent of remains available for return, while the Staten Island

Institute of Arts and Sciences has yet to make any of its stolen remains available for return.

Columbia and Princeton are the only

members of the Ivy League that have made

100 percent of Native American remains

available for return to Indigenous

communities.

A majority of each of Harvard, Brown, Dartmouth, and

Penn’s stolen remains are unavailable for return. As for

other institutions in New York City, the Brooklyn

Children’s Museum and the Rome Historical Society

have made 100 percent of remains available for return,

while the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences

has yet to make any of its stolen remains available for

return.
